title: My first post with equations and code
text:
This is a post with equations and code. An ancient way of estimating the value of \(\pi\) is to estimate the area \(A\) of a circle using some numerical method and then divide \(A\) by the diameter \(d\).

n = 1000 # sample size

x = runif(n)
y = runif(n)
r2 = x^2+y^2
A_4 = sum(r2<=1)/n

print(paste0('A simulation of size ',n,' leads to an estimated pi of ',4*A_4))

[1] "A simulation of size 1000 leads to an estimated pi of 3.112"

title: About
text:
Hi! My name is Filipe Paccetti, and I work as a senior quant in the financial sector. Besides having an interest in several quantitative fields ranging from complex differential geometry to deep learning, I am a kin reader on history and linguistics.
I hold a PhD in theoretical physics, having worked as a researcher in mathematical physics before joining the financial sector.

title: Compression is all there is
text:
[This post is under construction]
There has been a spurt of studies supporting the idea that deep network architectures such as the transformer are ingenious ways of compressing large volumes of unstructured data.
